executive_summary: Revenue growth for professional employer organizations (PEOs) has been solid during the current period despite significant volatility. The impact of COVID-19 severely disrupted the labor market, causing the national unemployment rate to more than double in 2020. This dragged down revenue for PEOs, but the economy's strong recovery led to a heightened need for the industry's services brought on a skyrocketing year-over-year jump in revenue in both 2021 and 2022.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE LABOR MARKET HAS MADE REVENUE VOLATILE
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: On a macro level, improvements in the labor market imply lower unemployment, a higher labor force participation rate (LFPR) and strong population growth, boosting demand for professional employer organizations (PEOs). The US economy was in the final stages of an expansion in the late 2010s following the 2008 financial crisis. As consumer spending surged, business revenue expanded, increasing hiring and boosting employment. More workers increased investment in PEOs. COVID-19 more than doubled the unemployment rate and led to the overall deterioration of the labor market in 2020, causing revenue to fall. As the economy recovered from the pandemic, hiring surged, increasing spending on PEOs and causing revenue to soar. These shifts in employment have enhanced revenue volatility during the current period.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: EXTERNAL FACTORS RESCUED THE INDUSTRY DURING COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In 2020, many companies were forced to downsize, pause or shut down operations, lowering the need for PEOs and reducing revenue. Following the initial hit of the pandemic, businesses turned to PEOs to help manage their companies. The virus made health insurance, paid leave and other benefits more important, so companies outsourced these services to PEOs.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Higher Interest Rates Have Constrained Revenue Growth Recently
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Expansive monetary policy, massive government spending and supply chain disruptions have caused inflation to soar recently. The Federal Reserve has been increasing interest rates significantly to combat higher prices. The elevated cost of borrowing has made it significantly more expensive for households to buy homes and companies to purchase new office space, causing residential and nonresidential construction to plunge. Revenue for the construction sector has cratered. Since construction companies comprise a notable share of revenue for PEOs, their disastrous performance has negatively affected the industry. Higher interest rates have also made it more difficult for consumers to splurge, constraining corporate profit. Lower corporate profit has made it harder for companies to afford PEOs, constraining revenue growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: PEOs Have Been Exposed to the Heightened Regulatory Environment
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: New industry-relevant regulations at the federal and state levels have regularly been introduced. For example, a new Kentucky law passed in 2022 has changed how PEOs are licensed. Five states (California, Hawaii, Minnesota, New Jersey, and New York) alone created nearly 2,400 new pieces of legislation related to COVID-19 that have impacted the way PEOs conduct business. In general, these new rules have increased licensing and certification requirements for PEOs and their employees, respectively. It's more difficult for small establishments to comply with these regulations, so many nonemployers and small players have left the industry, increasing market share concentration.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Economic Recovery Will Buoy Demand From Businesses
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite concerns related to high inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears, the US economy will grow at a modest pace during the outlook period. Business investment and consumer spending will benefit from higher GDP, causing revenue and profit for many corporations to increase. Higher corporate profit will give companies more funds to spend on external services, such as those offered by professional employer organizations (PEOs). As it becomes easier for companies to use PEOs, revenue will expand.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Solid economic conditions will also increase the number of businesses
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Solid economic conditions will also increase the number of businesses as more individuals set up their own companies to meet consumer demand. More businesses will raise the supply of potential customers for PEOs, so an increase in this driver will aid the industry's performance.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The labor market will likely improve slightly
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The number of employees in the economy will grow during the outlook period, driven by the declining unemployment rate and growing population. While negative real wage growth has led to some slacking participation, companies are expected to lift wages to encourage employment. While employment growth will be positive during the outlook period, the rate of increase will be constrained by external factors. Since COVID-19, businesses have become wary of hiring lots of workers. They're concerned about future outbreaks, which will inhibit revenue and raise companies' costs dramatically if they have many employees. Political forces may also raise minimum wages. This will increase costs for businesses, so many companies will hire at a slow pace to ensure they can afford a big jump in the minimum wage. Overall, relatively slow employment growth will cause revenue to rise at a meager pace.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry provide human relations management and administration services through a co-employment relationship. Corporations pay Professional employer organizations (PEOs) to administer their employee benefits. These include functions such as payroll, benefits, workers' compensation and training.
key_trends: External competitors can replace the industry. Internal HR departments, providers of certain HR services and insurance brokers are the most significant competitors for professional employer organizations.
The ability to negotiate insurance premiums is key. PEOs must secure favorable contracts, but premium rates are one of the major sources
Bargaining Power and Competitiveness The size of the PEO often determines the bargaining power of competitiveness in this industry.

Revenue Volatility Revenue volatility has been high during the current period. COVID-19 more than doubled the national unemployment rate, but rising production during the pandemic recovery has brought huge jumps in revenue.

Industry Outlook The industry will benefit from rising corporate profit and consumer spending during the outlook period. PEOs will also try to capture new revenue streams by reaching out to large corporations with existing internal HR departments.

Data Protection Companies in this industry must be able to provide the highest level of data protection. Information collected by professional employer organizations contains highly sensitive corporate and personal data.

Revenue Reporting Professional employer organizations (PEOs) typically report their revenues as gross billings. While this is atypical, PEOs do so since there are fewer payroll costs related to worksite employees.

Government Stimulus Impact Government stimulus has helped labor. Economic stimulus packages issued by the federal government in response to COVID-19 have protected many industries' workforces, aiding PEOs' performance during the current period.
Legal Regulations The industry is subject to a wide range of complex US and foreign laws. Many of these rules focus on tax and anti-fraud regulations.

Wages consistently account for the vast majority of revenue, which includes both PEO employees' wages and worksite employees' wages. Compensation's revenue share has crept downward since the pandemic as other categories have grown.
The size of PEOs partly determines profit in this industry. Larger PEOs can leverage their reputation and resources to command higher premiums that protect their profit.
PEOs' interest in certain states is partly explained by a favorable tax climate. Since Florida and Texas have very low taxes, PEOs more profitable in these states.
A region's population determines the concentration of PEOs. More populated areas tend to have a greater number of jobs overall, along with more corporate headquarters.

Comprehensive PEO services are the largest revenue stream for this industry. External competition for individual services is much higher, so PEOs tend to secure lucrative contracts that make them essential to businesses' success.
Demand for PEO services varies across different markets. Spending from the construction sector depends on interest rates, while demand from manufacturers is influenced by consumer spending.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Companies in the professional and technical service sector include consulting firms, law firms, accountants, engineering companies and market research firms. Professional and technical employees have a low risk of injury, so it's a popular market for PEOs since workers' compensation payouts are low. There is also a very high number of small- to medium-size enterprises operating in this market, which creates high demand for the industry's services. As corporate profit has surged, professional and technical service companies have been able to afford services offered by PEOs more easily, so this segment's revenue share has grown during the current period.

Manufacturers, retailers and distributors in this segment are mostly small- to medium-size enterprises that use PEO co-employment HR management and administration services to focus more on core functions. As the recovery from the pandemic has caused consumer spending to surge, revenue for manufacturers, retailers and distributors has expanded significantly, causing their revenue share to rise during the current period.

Information technology (IT) companies include organizations that provide software development, digital transformation and other related services. Employees in the IT industry rarely get injured, so PEOs can pay significantly lower insurance premiums for these clients compared with more labor-intensive jobs such as those in manufacturing and construction. As digital transformation makes the IT industry more complex, companies have sought to outsource the administration of employee benefits to third-party providers like PEOs, boosting demand for industry services.

This segment includes finance, insurance and real estate companies. Similar to the professional and technical services and IT markets, PEOs prefer to provide services to this market because of the relatively low risk to employees while on job sites. Financial institutions have displayed more business amid rising stock prices recently, causing this segment's revenue share to surge during the current period.

Other markets include nonprofit organizations, medical institutions, arts organizations and transportation companies. Strong economic growth increases spending from companies in this segment. Despite the influence of general trends, each market is driven by niche factors relevant to these markets. The US economy has expanded recently, but the strong performance of other sectors has caused other markets' revenue share to creep downward during the current period.

products_and_services.product_description: These services are sold in bundles, so it's impossible to derive the precise segmentation for this industry's products. For this reason, the product segmentation for PEOs is broken down by the size of the businesses served.

The share of revenue going to businesses with fewer than 50 employees has surged during the current period, as the growing number of workers has encouraged smaller companies to outsource the administration of employee benefits.

tier_2_suppliers: Public Relations Firms in the US
Employment & Recruiting Agencies in the US
Office Staffing & Temp Agencies in the US
tier_1_buyers: Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US
Scientific Research & Development in the US
Finance and Insurance in the US
tier_2_buyers: Healthcare and Social Assistance in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The number of employees refers to the size of the nonfarm workforce in the United States. An increase in overall employment leads to a rise in demand for the industry's services because PEOs serve clients across all sectors of the economy. Employment growth also causes some small businesses to grow to a size that would benefit from outsourcing HR management. The number of employees in the United States is expected to increase in 2023, representing a potential opportunity for industry operators.

business_locations.location_description: Within the Southeast region, Florida is the largest state by the number of establishments. Professional employer organization's (PEOs) strong interest in the state of Florida is primarily explained by the favorable tax climate, as Florida has the lowest individual income tax in the country. The region also holds the largest portion of the population, attracting more downstream companies and boosting demand for PEOs.

Within the West region, California holds the majority of PEOs. While California is attractive in terms of its addressable market, California's unfavorable tax environment discourages some PEOs from operating in this state. Many companies are based out of California, including retailers, professional service providers, manufacturers and technology companies. This results in higher demand for PEOs.

Within the Southwest region, Texas has the most establishments. The state's large population primarily explains the strong presence of PEOs in Texas. Following the pandemic, many companies moved to states with lower operating costs. This resulted in many companies migrating to Texas, causing more PEOs to base operations in the region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The SBEA, which came into effect in July 2016, created a standardized, national regulatory framework for the industry that includes a certification process for licensed professional employer organizations (PEOs), minimum capital requirements and other standards.

The measures taken at every level of government to prevent the spread of COVID-19 resulted in unprecedented regulations. The regulations included quarantines, shelter-in-place orders and business closures for nonessential businesses.

Since PEOs are by definition the legal employers of their client's workers, they're mostly responsible for all labor-related taxes and laws, along with any penalties or insurance claims arising from employee-related operations.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Low and steady level of industry assistance.
High and increasing level of competition.

basis_points.basis_description: External competitors like internal HR departments, providers of certain HR services and insurance brokers are significant competitors.
The ability to negotiate favorable insurance premium contracts is key, as premium rates are a major source of competitiveness.
The size of the PEO often determines its bargaining power.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Strong brand recognition attracts larger clients
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger companies prefer outsourcing to trusted, big PEOs due to rising fraud cases, preventing smaller companies from gaining significant share.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Major players benefit from higher bargaining power
concentration_points.concentration_description: Larger players can negotiate better benefits with providers like health insurers, keeping prices low and boosting demand.
Many PEOs operate locally where their customers are, limiting expansion and contributing to industry fragmentation and low concentration.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Make Up the Vast Majority of Revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The payroll of client employees is by far the most significant cost for PEOs. In addition to remitting payroll, companies directly pay other employee-related costs, including payroll (Social Security and Medicare) taxes, retirement benefit costs and workers' compensation expenses.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Include Insurance and Other Employee Benefits
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases for this industry primarily include costs associated with workers' compensation, state unemployment payments and benefits coverage for worksite employees.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While the role of technology has increased, professional employer organizations continue to depend on customer service and satisfaction. As a result, employing individuals with strong prior experience in human resources is a critical success factor.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fluctuations in the Labor Market Enhance Revenue Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry is sensitive to trends in the labor market. When the number of workers in the economy rises, revenue increases and vice versa. In general, the labor market grows when the economy grows.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Companies' Willingness to Outsource Benefit Administration Doesn't Fluctuate Much Over a Short Period of Time
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for outsourcing is influenced by such factors as the share of the remote workforce in the economy, the value of the labor force and companies' focus on cost-cutting measures as compared to cyclical economic trends. These factors tend to change smoothly, rarely causing unexpected spikes in revenue and helping moderate volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The Industry is Characterized by Gradual Improvements
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: PEOs gradually improve their digital technology instead of focusing on breakthrough innovations. Companies have purchased new companies to boost software functionality while hiring better software developers and engineers to improve data protection. Smaller PEOs have also increasingly invested in mobile apps to connect with small businesses in the hope of attracting more customers.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche service or bundle its services to attract clients?
FAQs.answer: Most professional employer organizations offer a bundle but compete with industries that provide fewer services. Being able to cater to service packages to better suit clients' needs could provide a competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to establish a good reputation?
FAQs.answer: Players often differentiate themselves by having a good reputation so clients can feel comfortable relying on them for co-employment.

FAQs.question: Does your company target a particular market segment or provide for a broad range of markets?
FAQs.answer: The Professional Employer Organizations industry is fragmented and most companies cater to only a few clients and avoid riskier industries like construction and manufacturing. The industry association, NAPEO, lobbies the federal government for favorable legislation.

FAQs.question: Has your company implemented practices to offer more competitive benefits packages?
FAQs.answer: Professional employer organizations with many worksite employees (WSE) can negotiate more comprehensive benefits packages with insurance and benefit provider companies.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to cater to more clients by adopting new technology?
FAQs.answer: New practices such as internet-based employment can lower the need for in-person meetings and increase efficiency for professional employer organizations.

FAQs.question: Are internet-based technologies, such as cloud-based storage and video conferencing, affecting your business?
FAQs.answer: Video conferencing has increased in popularity and can be beneficial for professional employer organizations to adopt. Additionally, many major companies have increasingly offered cloud-based storage as a part of their service packages.

FAQs.question: Is obtaining state certification or licensing a challenge for your business?
FAQs.answer: Most states require licensing or certification, and many regulations are state-specific. Industry associations such as the National Association for Professional Employer Organizations (NAPEO) offer tools and information to support PEOs.

FAQs.question: Are you aware of changes in health care reform and how it may impact your business?
FAQs.answer: Companies are responsible for providing employees with health insurance and complying with regulations regardless of how policy changes. Tracking healthcare policy is crucial to remain compliant in this industry.

FAQs.question: Have you negotiated with insurance and employee benefits companies to lower costs?
FAQs.answer: Professional employer organizations with a large number of worksite employees can negotiate better deals with insurance and employee benefits.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: The majority of technology purchases are for computers and software. Consequently, new purchases are really only necessary when a game-changing technology comes out or for regular updates.

FAQs.question: How quickly can new technology be adopted? Does your company keep up to date with the latest technology?
FAQs.answer: Professional employer organizations must adopt new payroll processing, tax payment and other benefit processing software and systems and delivery to clients and employees via the Internet to remain competitive.

FAQs.question: How does your company establish and maintain a good reputation?
FAQs.answer: Due to a relatively high number of tax frauds occurring in this industry before the Small Business Efficiency Act was enacted in 2016, a good reputation has been critical in getting new clients. An increasing number of professional employer organizations have been obtaining industry-relevant certifications, such as the Voluntary Certification Program for Professional Employer Organizations (CPEO) by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).

FAQs.question: How have you been affected by government policies? How have you dealt with the negative effects of government policies?
FAQs.answer: Companies must have a thorough knowledge and understanding of state and federal employment regulations to comply with tax and other laws.

FAQs.question: Do you closely monitor your competitors? What strategies do you use to compete with other professional employer organizations?
FAQs.answer: The Human Resources and Benefits Administration industry provides similar services and competes directly with professional employer organizations.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the number of businesses in the United States? How does a rising number affect demand for your company?
FAQs.answer: Since small- to medium-sized enterprises generate the majority of revenue for professional employer organizations, an increase in the number of...
